text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This transmittal reissues existing procedures. Editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Website addresses, legal references, code sections and IRM references were reviewed and updated accordingly.
This IRM section supersedes IRM 8.24.2, dated September 25,

Levy Appeals

) This Internal Revenue Manual provides instructions for Settlement Officers, Appeals Officers, Appeals Account Resolution Specialists and Account and Appeals Processing Support (APS) employees working jeopardy levy appeals cases. (
) Part

(Collection Process) of the IRM and the Internal Revenue Code are primary authorities for the legal and procedural requirements that Appeals follow in making determinations on jeopardy levy appeals cases. (
) Normally, the notices and waiting periods described in IRC
and Collec- tion’s IRM

- Notice of Levy, Background, Pre-Levy Actions, Appeals - on Levy & Post-Levy Actions. must be adhered to before property can be levied. However, if collection is in jeopardy, property can be levied sooner. of two situations will be in effect. (
) There may be a jeopardy or termination assessment occurring also. See

- Guidelines for Cases with Special Issues. If so, there is an immediate notice and demand, which is followed by a jeopardy levy. In this instance the taxpayer is often also appealing the assessment. (

) Or there may already be an assessment before collection is identified as in jeopardy. Normally the jeopardy is not identified until the case is being worked by a revenue officer. Note: In every situation where a jeopardy levy occurs without a jeopardy or nation assessment, the Service has already assessed the tax liability normal procedures. Example: There may be a prompt assessment on a voluntarily filed return. the taxpayer starts transferring or dissipating assets to place them beyond the reach of the government. Property can be levied, even though the usual waiting periods after notices have not expired. (
) A jeopardy levy without a jeopardy or termination assessment can happen; (cid:
) After tax is assessed, but before the notice and demand normally by IRC
(a) is issued, provided immediate notice and demand is to the taxpayer; (cid:
) After the notice and demand is issued, but before ten days have passed; (cid:
) After the ten day notice and demand period ends, but before the
day notice of intent to levy and notice of a right to a hearing have been or (cid:
) After the notice of intent to levy and notice of a right to a hearing have been issued, but before the
days for the taxpayer to request a have passed. Note: The taxpayer may request an administrative or judicial review of the levy action under IRC
during any of these periods. If a jeopardy levy occurs before the IRC
(a) notice is given, the Service will issue a notice under IRC
(f) within a reasonable period of time to give the taxpayer an opportunity to seek CDP appeal rights under that section. (
) In general, no levy can be made in the following circumstances: (cid:
) On the appearance date of a summons, (cid:
) When there is a pending or active installment agreement, (

(Collection Process) of the IRM and the Internal Revenue Code are primary authorities for the legal and procedural requirements that Appeals follow in making determinations on jeopardy levy appeals cases. (

and Collec- tion’s IRM

- Notice of Levy, Background, Pre-Levy Actions, Levy Appeals - on Levy & Post-Levy Actions. must be adhered to before property can be levied. However, if collection is in jeopardy, property can be levied sooner. of two situations will be in effect. (

- Guidelines for Cases with Special Issues. If so, there is an immediate notice and demand, which is followed by a jeopardy levy. In this instance the taxpayer is often also appealing the assessment. (
) Or there may already be an assessment before collection is identified as in jeopardy. Normally the jeopardy is not identified until the case is being worked by a revenue officer.
Note: In every situation where a jeopardy levy occurs without a jeopardy or termi- nation assessment, the Service has already assessed the tax liability through normal procedures.

There may be a prompt assessment on a voluntarily filed return. Then, the taxpayer starts transferring or dissipating assets to place them beyond the reach of the government. Property can be levied, even though the usual waiting periods after notices have not expired.
A jeopardy levy without a jeopardy or termination assessment can happen;
(cid:
) After tax is assessed, but before the notice and demand normally required by IRC
(a) is issued, provided immediate notice and demand is given to the taxpayer; (cid:
) After the notice and demand is issued, but before ten days have passed; (cid:
) After the ten day notice and demand period ends, but before the
day notice of intent to levy and notice of a right to a hearing have been issued; or (cid:
) After the notice of intent to levy and notice of a right to a hearing have been issued, but before the
days for the taxpayer to request a hearing have passed.
have passed. Note: The taxpayer may request an administrative or judicial review of the jeopardy levy action under IRC
during any of these periods. If a jeopardy levy occurs before the IRC
(a) notice is given, the Service will issue a CDP notice under IRC
(f) within a reasonable period of time to give the taxpayer an opportunity to seek CDP appeal rights under that section. (

2 8.24 Collection Appeals Program and Jeopardy Levy Appeals
(cid:
) For
days following the termination of an installment agreement during an appeal of the termination, (cid:
) When a rejected installment agreement can be appealed or is being appealed, (cid:

) While a rejected offer in compromise can be appealed or is being appealed, or (cid:

However, in the circumstances listed in (4), if collection is in jeopardy a jeopardy levy may be issued.
Exception: However, in the circumstances listed in (
), if collection is in jeopardy a jeopardy levy may be issued. (
) If collection is believed to be in jeopardy, a jeopardy levy may be issued any time after assessment but before

days from the notice and demand. The jeopardy levy requires the approval of the Chief Counsel or his/her delegate. However, this type of jeopardy levy will be very rare as it is normally possible only if a Revenue Officer or other Service employee secures a taxpayer’s return and subsequently discovers that a jeopardy situation exists, after as- sessment but before the end of the required waiting period. Normally, a Revenue Officer would not receive a taxpayer’s delinquent account until well after the expiration of the required notice period. See IRM
and IRM
for Collection jeopardy levy procedures. Note: The notice and demand gives the taxpayer
days to pay. See IRM - Notice of Levy, Background, Pre-Levy Actions, Restrictions on Levy & Levy Actions. (
) Jeopardy and termination assessments require a notice and demand before levy but there is no waiting period for levy after the notice and demand has been made. Under the authority of IRC
(a) , administrative appeals with judicial review are now available for jeopardy levies following regular assess- ments, or for jeopardy levies following jeopardy or termination assessments. (
) Jeopardy levy determinations basically have the same criteria as jeopardy as- sessments, (i.e., is the collection in jeopardy?), as described in Policy Statement P-
See IRM
Appeals determines if the levy was able under the circumstances. The time frames for working cases, indicated IRM
should be followed in working jeopardy levy cases also. Jeopardy levy appeals will be received from Collection on a Form

, Document Transmittal. Collection Advisory and Insolvency (AI) - Advisory acts as liaison for these cases. Local Appeals and Collection offices may work out their own transmittal and liaison procedures for faster case processing. (

) The Collection file, related to the jeopardy levy, received by Appeals should indicate the status of the levy proceeds. Collection sends a letter with each jeopardy levy that instructs the recipient to hold the levy proceeds for

to allow the taxpayer time to appeal. If a taxpayer immediately appeals a jeopardy levy, Collection can request that the levied entity continue to hold levy proceeds until Appeals has made its determination on whether or not the jeopardy levy was “reasonable under the circumstances ”. Also, in a separate requirement, IRC
(c) requires banks to hold levy proceeds for
days after service of a levy, prior to giving the proceeds to the Service. This
day hold period applies to all levies on banks. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
F
) If collection is believed to be in jeopardy, a jeopardy levy may be issued any time after assessment but before

days from the notice and demand. The jeopardy levy requires the approval of the Chief Counsel or his/her delegate. However, this type of jeopardy levy will be very rare as it is normally possible only if a Revenue Officer or other Service employee secures a taxpayer’s return and subsequently discovers that a jeopardy situation exists, after as- sessment but before the end of the required waiting period. Normally, a Revenue Officer would not receive a taxpayer’s delinquent account until well after the expiration of the required notice period. See IRM
and IRM
for Collection jeopardy levy procedures.

If collection is believed to be in jeopardy, a jeopardy levy may be issued any time after assessment but before 30 days from the notice and demand. The jeopardy levy requires the approval of the Chief Counsel or his/her delegate. However, this type of jeopardy levy will be very rare as it is normally only if a Revenue Officer or other Service employee secures a taxpayer’s return and subsequently discovers that a jeopardy situation exists, after as- sessment but before the end of the required waiting period. Normally, a Revenue Officer would not receive a taxpayer’s delinquent account until well after the expiration of the required notice period. See IRM 5.1.4 and IRM
) A jeopardy levy requires the same conditions that would allow a jeopardy as- sessment. See IRS policy statement P-
in IRM
, regarding assessments, and for the conditions under which a jeopardy assessment will be made. (
) Collection’s IRM
, Jeopardy Levy without a Jeopardy Assessment, explains the administrative, legal and approval procedures that must be followed before a jeopardy level can be issued. (
) IRC
specifies that jeopardy levies may be administratively appealed and challenged in court. Statutory authority to levy is contained in IRC

For normal, non-jeopardy assessments, which are in balance due status, there is generally a series of notices, prior to the delinquent account being issued to the Automated Collection System (ACS) or to a Revenue Officer. The first notice under IRC
(a) is a
calendar day (
business days if the amount is $
or more) notice and demand notice. The notice under
(d) is the
day intent to levy notice. See IRM
for additional mation regarding notice and demand procedures. In the case of jeopardy notification of the right of appeal and right to review under IRC
is available. (
) In order for a taxpayer to be entitled to an administrative appeal and judicial review under IRC
the following conditions must have been met: a. The jeopardy levy was issued within the
days from notice and (assessment and first notice), b. The taxpayer must file a written protest with the Area Director within
days of the date on Letter

, Notice of Jeopardy Levy and Right of Appeal, requesting a redetermination of whether the levy is reasonable under the circumstances, and c. The written protest must be sent to the address listed on the Letter

) The issue is whether the jeopardy levy is reasonable under the (collection is truly in jeopardy). If the appeal is rejected, the taxpayer can obtain judicial review of the jeopardy levy. If any of the liabilities on the jeopardy levy were being considered in Tax Court before the making of the jeopardy levy, the taxpayer can obtain judicial review of the jeopardy levy by the Tax Court. (
) If the jeopardy levy was issued after
days from the notice and demand the taxpayer has not already been issued appeal rights under IRC
, then Collection must notify the taxpayer of their appeal rights under IRC
IRM
The taxpayer has
days from the date of the Letter
A(CG) to request a Collection Due Process (CDP) hearing. The taxpayer must request a CDP hearing under IRC
in order to be entitled to judicial under that section. See IRM
, Collection Due Process, for additional mation about taxpayers’ rights to appeal under IRC

) If the taxpayer appeals or states that a suit is being filed, Collection will AI-Advisory and seek advice from Counsel, as needed. The local Appeals Office will handle the administrative appeal. Collection will also advise the Internal Revenue Manual
In order for a taxpayer to be entitled to an administrative appeal and judicial review under IRC 7429 the following conditions must have been met:

recipient(s) to delay paying over the funds while the appeal is considered using Letter 2438(CG), Jeopardy Levy Letter to Third Party Recipient.
Letter
(CG), Jeopardy Levy Letter to Third Party Recipient. (

) If the taxpayer has received all the pre-levy notices and the waiting periods have passed, the taxpayer can appeal under the Collection Appeals Program (CAP) or request an equivalent hearing. The taxpayer cannot go to court if the taxpayer disagrees with Appeals’ decision in a CAP or equivalent hearing. See IRM
, Collection Appeal Rights, IRM
, Collection Appeals Program (CAP), and IRM
, Collection Due Process, for additional information on CAP and equivalent hearings.
